you for coming uh I'm Leo Jnowski i'm a principal solutions architect at AWS and
we also have Henry Han here he's a senior technical product manager for AWS codear and
so during this session uh we're going to be talking about first we're just going to uh talk about what is DevOps what is
the Amazon DevOps story um we're going to talk about our portfolio of code
services and then Henry is going to dive deep into codear and talk about what it
is and what it does and do a demo of it for you
so today's software creation distribution is easier and faster than ever uh we see that startups can take on
giants with little to no funding ahead of time getting your software into the hands of millions is only a download
away and your ability to move fast is paramount to your ability to fight off
disruption and so why why do we care about DevOps why is it important uh well
according to the uh puppet labs uh state of the DevOps survey uh this is from the
2015 survey uh they find that high performing IT organizations deploy 30
times more frequently with 200 times shorter lead times and they have 60 times fewer failures and can recover 160
times faster from failure it also finds that lean management and continuous delivery practices create the
conditions for delivering value faster and more sustainably and high performance is
achievable whether your apps are green field brownfield or legacy so even if you have apps that can't fully take
advantage of you know microservices architecture um you can still achieve a lot from adopting DevOps so what is
DevOps though right uh DevOps is a combination of cultural philosophies
practices and tools uh and these increase an organization's ability to deliver applications and services at a
high velocity uh and allows you to evolve and improve your products at a
faster pace than if you use traditional software development and infrastructure management processes
uh this speed then allows companies and organizations to better serve their customers and compete more effectively
in the market so DevOps also aside from the
technical part of it has a cultural component too so what that means is that you have your developers and your
operators coming together and there's no more silos so you don't have developers writing code and then throwing it over
the wall to operators to deploy and you don't have operators who don't know what they're actually deploying or how it
works or why so you have shared responsibility across teams you have ownership so the team that writes a
product owns the product from writing the code to building the code to testing the code to deploying the code and
maintaining it once it's up and running and you have shared visibility and communication so everybody that's on the
service team for a specific product they can see all the metrics on whether it's up or not how it's performing and
there's a unified communications channel whether you're a developer or you're an ops
so one thing that we see a lot of our customers doing um to adopt DevOps is to
move away from large monolithic architectures to smaller decoupled services so you break your applications
down to smaller smaller pieces and you can iterate on those pieces um in parallel and a lot more a lot
quicker and so the combination of microservices and increased release
frequency means you have way more deployments and that can mean operational challenges if you're
deploying you know 10 times a day 100 times a day uh versus you know previously you could have been deploying
your app maybe once a quarter that means you can't manually do your deployments anymore you have to do them
automatically so you have to do automation and to in order to avoid those operational challenges uh so you
need ways to release the software safely and reliably with automation and so that's where continuous integration and
continuous delivery and continuous deployment come in and we'll talk about what that actually means another
practice that's really important is treating your infrastructure as code um so you treat your infrastructure just
like you treat your application code now one of the really nice things about AWS in general is that you can do almost
anything you can do in the web console through our APIs which means you can script things and you can automate
things uh so we have a service called cloud for that allows you to use templates to declare the AWS resources
that you want to launch and provision them and then use that template to actually provision them you can then
check these templates into a version control system such as GitHub and iterate on them just as you iterate on a
piece of code uh you can then easily share the templates replicate environments um across you know prod and
dev for example and it ultimately saves you a lot of time and also reduces the room for error because everything can be
traced back down to a cloudformation template another thing that's really important with DevOps is to have strong
monitoring and logging so you want to analyze your metrics and your logs you want to look at application logs and
access logs and things like cloud trail logs in AWS and VPC flow logs so you
want to know what's going on at all times and you want to understand the real time uh performance of your infrastructure and your application um
so X-ray which is another service that uh I went into uh preview today u can
help you there too with both Lambda functions and regular uh instances and so you want to also set up automation
for your monitoring and logging so you want to get actionable alerts on metrics that matter and you want to act on those
alerts ideally with automatic remediation so just some of the benefits
of DevOps right so you have teams that work more efficiently and effectively uh because they're working together you're
using automation to work effectively and release software uh more rapidly you
bake reliability and security into your automated practices so a good idea a
good thing to do is in your continuous integration continuous uh deployment
pipeline bake in security testing automatically right so every time you bake a new Amazon machine image for
example you you run a test against it to make sure that it's patched properly you can do that kind of thing um this
ultimately allows you to scale up quicker uh and to build your software at
a faster pace so let's take a look at uh an example here and that's Amazon.com
let's take a look at how Amazon as a company actually evolved into a microservices architecture so in 2001 uh
Amazon.com was a big monolithic application uh and it had a hierarchal organization
scheme and by 2009 it had evolved into smaller decoupled services so if you
look at you know the amazon.com website um each part of that website is a different service they each have their
own uh architectures and SLAs they have to meet and so on and so forth and it
also evolved into this concept of two pizza teams so what a two pizza team generally means is if you can't feed
your team uh with two pizzas your team's too big this is the general sizing advice for your team and so under this
model things went a lot better we were releasing software faster but we felt
that we could still improve and so in 2009 we conducted a study the study was called understanding Amazon's software
development process through data and we wanted to find out how long it takes for code to go from check-in uh to being
available in production this included the time that it took to build test and deploy our software and we learned that
this was taking a long time actually uh it was taking on the order of weeks and we didn't want it to take weeks we
wanted it to take hours maybe maybe even shorter than that right and so what we
found out was a lot of our processes had a lot of human manual work involved and so that is what was actually taking up
most of the time uh so developers would use tickets or emails to track their release process so for example
developers could email uh or take or ticket a bunch of other developers to run a build at which point those
requests would pile up and queue up be before being run as a batch and then once the build was done there'd be new
tickets to cut to deploy the the software and these would also batch up so there's just a lot of time being spent waiting for humans to do
something so as a result when you add up all the waiting uh this would take weeks
and we wanted it to take hours and not weeks so we started building tools to
automate our release process for software and so the the first thing that resulted from this was our pipeline
service uh so this was an internal service and it automated these parts of
our software release process where we were waiting for humans so it would automatically transition code from
check-in to build to test to deployments and we saw a lot of benefits for our
developers it was way faster it was safer there weren't there was a lot less manual work going on uh it was a
standardized process so uh anyone had the option of using pipelines and uh so
even if you moved across teams you'd be used to a common uh deployment uh uh pipeline and uh there's also
visualization of the process so you could see where your code was if you had committed some code you could see was it
in testing was it in deployment and so this continued to work really well and by 2014 we had thousands of service
teams across Amazon we were building a lot of microservices we were practicing continuous delivery we had many
environments from staging to beta to production and so in 2014 uh we did 50
million deploys during that year across Amazon so every year we also conduct a
survey uh where of our software developers and we kind of ask them you know what uh tools are you happy with
what tools could be better um you know things that we could do to improve their lives as developers and make their jobs
easier so we that year in 2014 uh we found that only one specific service was
correlated statistically with happier developers and that is our pipeline service so I guess you could say the
continuous delivery means happier developers and so when we tell the story
to our customers a lot of times we hear how do how do you uh how do where do you
start to go on this journey so it's actually not a simple answer it's going to be different for every customer um it
can involve you know changing your organization your culture your processes uh but one thing that we see that's
common across almost all of our customers is the need to have a good
pipeline right between the different phases of your application life cycle
and so with that let me talk about our code services really quickly we've got
code pipeline code deploy code commit code build and here's how these map to
the uh software release process so for uh version control we have code commit
is a managed version control uh service uh it is fully compatible with git it's integrated with IM uh for build we have
code build so if you want to build some artifacts or docker containers not have to worry about spinning up the docker
containers or running the worker instances for that we got code build uh for unit testing you can use code build
for uh end-to-end testing uh UI testing security testing you probably want to use some thirdparty tooling and for
deploying your code uh whether to EC2 instances or to on premise uh servers you can use code deploy which is our
deployment service and for the orchestration of going between these stages you would use code
pipeline so that takes us to how do I put all this together if I have a piece
of software how do I know which of these I need to use um how do I set them up really quickly and that's where CodeStar
comes in so uh Henry Han is going to come up here and talk to you about CodeStar and do a demo for you as
well all right thank you Leo um let me go ahead and get something set up here
